definitions: The theory that things in the world exist as imperfect copies or approximations of abstract or eternally existing patterns or archetypes; especially the theory that created things are patterned after ideas eternally existing in the mind of God. Compare "exemplar". Chiefly historical.

notes.text: In Christian theology the theory was most prominent in the 13th century, influencing the work of St Thomas Aquinas (1225–74) and St Bonaventure (1221–74).

definitions: The doctrine that the atonement of Christ is of value to humanity purely as a moral example, especially as a lesson in the positive value of sacrifice and suffering for the benefit of others.

notes.text: One of the earliest theologians to interpret the death of Christ in this way was Peter Abelard (1079–1142), though exemplarist ideas may date back further still.
